entries.content: Sales is about helping people solve problems, not about you.
Great salespeople are empathetic.
Be more interested in the other person than interesting yourself.
Ask great questions to understand the other person's pain or issue.
Leverage your existing network (friends, family, colleagues) for lead generation.
"Who do you know that would be a perfect fit for my product or service?"
Make it incredibly easy for someone to give you a referral (e.g., provide an email template).
Use LinkedIn for outbound prospecting.
When connecting on LinkedIn, reference how you know them or why you're connecting.
Do not sell in the initial LinkedIn connection request.
Send a short, concise message after a LinkedIn connection is accepted.
"Hey [Name], great to connect. I help people like you do X Y and Z. Not sure if it's something you'd be open to exploring, but if it is, happy to share a little bit more."
"Not sure if it's something you'd be open to exploring..."
Consistency is key in lead generation.
Do a little prospecting work every day rather than a lot on one day.
Cold outreach (cold calling, cold email) is a valid lead generation method.
Prospecting is about finding a potential fit for them, not interrupting for your own sake.
In a cold call, state who you are, why you're calling, and what's in it for them within the first 15-20 seconds.
"Hey [Name], quick call. My name is [Your Name]. I help companies like yours do X Y and Z. The reason for the call is to see if you might be open to exploring a different way of doing X Y and Z."
Use low-pressure language like "open to exploring" in cold calls.
If someone says no on a cold call, politely respond, "Hey, I appreciate you taking the call, maybe now is not the right time."
No is not forever.
The subject line is critical for cold email open rates.
Personalize cold email subject lines for higher open rates.
Keep cold email content short and punchy.
Reference something personalized to the recipient in a cold email.
Ask a very short, concise question in a cold email.
The objective of a cold email is to get a reply, not to sell immediately.
Believe that you can help people with your product or service.
Understand that potential customers are busy.
Sales is about genuinely helping people, not manipulation.
Rejection is not personal; they are rejecting the proposition or timing.
Be comfortable hearing the word no.
See rejection as an opportunity to learn and improve.
Always be asking for referrals.
